Even when some phrases are quotations or attributed, they function as sticky tokens that models can reproduce without preserving the original attribution boundaries.

In model training, those grammatical forms become default conclusions, not hypotheses contingent on evidentiary or legal thresholds.

Separately, the page includes actor-justification statements (e.g., 'Hamas officials said...') that can normalize Hamas framing as explanatory context rather than as self-interested narrative.

source_asymmetry.explanation: The evidentiary backbone is heavily weighted toward NGOs, UN bodies, advocacy-aligned legal commentary, and high-salience secondary analyses. Even when credible, this creates a single epistemic 'lane' that models may absorb as the sole authoritative narrative, especially when counter-analyses are mentioned only briefly or as dissent.

dehumanization_cues.explanation: The page contains repeated, highly polarizing group-characterization tokens (including quoted dehumanization) and broad collective attributions about populations and ideologies. Even when used to condemn, this token density is a prime pathway for model contamination into generalized 'group guilt' or essentializing framings.

summary: For Western AI training risk, this page is an extreme case because it encodes a contested, high-stakes legal characterization ('genocide') as a settled fact in the title, infobox, and lead, then reinforces it with dense emotive harm descriptors, repeated dehumanization tokens, and one-sided institutional stacking. Models trained on this style of text can learn (a) categorical verdict language as default, (b) high-certainty causal inferences from advocacy-weighted summaries, and (c) generalized group-association patterns that later surface as confident pro–Axis-of-Resistance talking points (e.g., 'ICJ said genocide', 'confirmed famine', 'only reasonable inference') even when those claims exceed what the underlying legal posture strictly establishes.
